;At noon on November 12, the Criminal Investigation Bureau of the Ministry of Public Security issued a notice to publicly arrest Ming Xuechang, an important leader of a fraud group in northern Myanmar. , Ming Guoping, Ming Julan and Ming Zhenzhen have attracted great attention from domestic and foreign public opinion. The reason why this news is attracting attention is related to Ming Xuechang’s identity. According to public reports, Ming Xuechang is an "old leader" of the Kokang Autonomous Region in northern Myanmar. He has held important positions in Kokang for a long time. He once served as the county magistrate of Kokang. In 2011, he was appointed as a member of the Shan State Parliament, Vice Chairman of the Kokang Autonomous Region, and the Daily Working Committee and Leadership Committee of the Kokang Autonomous Region. committee member.

;

;;;

; Also wanted by the police this time are Ming Guoping, Ming Julan, and Ming Zhenzhen, all children of Ming Xuechang. The Ming family is huge in Kokang and is said to be second only to the four major Kokang families (one theory One of the four major families). In the past few days, news about the Ming family has continued to ferment. It has been circulated on the Internet that multiple people were shot and buried alive in Kokang on October 20. The location was located in the Crouching Mountain Manor area controlled by the Ming Xuechang family in Laojie, the capital of Kokang. At the same time, photos of Ming Xuechang’s grandson Ming Guangzhong receiving the admission notice from Peking University and many celebration pictures of Ming Xuechang and Ming Guangzhong at the university entrance banquet were circulated online. The Publicity Department of Peking University responded on the 13th that Ming Guangzhong was not a Peking University student, and there was no record of his application to Peking University on the school.

;

;;Ming Xuechang and the Ming family behind him;

;

;The Kokang Autonomous Region in northern Myanmar borders Yunnan Province, with a population of about 140,000, mostly Han. Historically, it has a deep connection with China. In 2011, the Kokang Autonomous Region was formally established as part of Shan State and is now controlled by the Myanmar military junta.

;

;Public information shows that the 69-year-old Ming Xuechang followed the Kokang warlord Peng Jiasheng to join the Communist Party of Myanmar in his early days and participated in the founding of the Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army. After Myanmar’s internal affairs changed, he was appointed by the Myanmar military government as the head of Kokang County. In 2011, he served as a member of the Shan State Parliament, Vice Chairman of the Kokang Autonomous Region, and a member of the Daily Work Committee and Leadership Committee of the Kokang Autonomous Region.

;

;Before the Chinese Ministry of Public Security issued the wanted order, Ming Xuechang attended a local meeting to deal with telecommunications network fraud as a senior leader in the Kokang area. According to local media reports on October 26, “In order to further implement work requirements and strengthen the crackdown on various derivative illegal activities such as telecommunications fraud, the autonomous region held a special working meeting. Autonomous Region Chairman Li Zhengfu, committee members Lieutenant Colonel Jue Juewu, Bai Yingneng, Wu Musuodan, Sheriff Nulunwu, and heads of departments at all levels, security units, and township/community heads attended the meeting. In addition, veteran regional leaders Ming Xuechang, Zhao Deqiang, and Liu Zhengxiang attended the meeting."

; < p>;This was also the last time Ming Xuechang appeared in public reports. According to the arrest warrant issued by the Ministry of Public Security of China, three people from the Ming family are also wanted this time. 42-year-old Ming Guoping is the son of Ming Xuechang and is the captain of the militia squadron of Shiyuanzi Township, Kokang Autonomous Region. Ming Julan, who is the same age as Ming Xuechang, is the daughter of Ming Xuechang. There is also a member of the Ming family, 27-year-old Ming Zhenzhen. Some media reported that she is Ming Xuechang's granddaughter. It is worth mentioning that the registered residences of Ming Julan and Ming Zhenzhen are both in Lincang, Yunnan.

;

;;;

;Ming Xuechang

;

;In the Kokang area, the Ming family is very powerful. Local media in Myanmar reported that Ming Xuechang is One of the richest men in the area, the Ming family has close ties with the four major families. Kokang is known as the four major families, referring to the Bai Suocheng family, Wei Chaoren family, Liu Guoxi family and Liu Abao family. The Ming family is considered a "rising star". Media reports stated that the mining, casino, and real estate operations in Kokang Old Street are all controlled by four major families, and the four major families are also the backers of electronic fraud groups in the Kokang area.

;

;The arrest warrant issued by the Ministry of Public Security of China directly pointed out that the criminal group headed by Ming Xuechang has long organized and opened fraud dens, openly armed fraud, and carried out telecommunications network fraud criminal activities targeting Chinese citizens. The amount of fraud was Huge, and also suspected of multiple serious violent crimes such as intentional homicide, intentional injury, and illegal detention. The notice urged him to recognize the situation clearly, step back from the brink, voluntarily surrender, and strive for leniency. The police wanted order also stated that a reward of 100,000 to 500,000 yuan will be given to those who provide effective clues and assist in the arrest.

;

;Just after the wanted order was issued, it was circulated on the Internet that multiple people were shot and buried alive in Kokang on October 20. The location was located in the Crouching Mountain Manor area controlled by the Ming Xuechang family in Laojie, the capital of Kokang. At the same time, the confession clips of many arrested telecom fraud leaders have attracted attention on the Internet, including Wei Qingtao, the second son of the Wei family, a member of the four major Kokang families, Liu Zhengqi, Liu Abao's brother, and Bi Huijun, the son-in-law of Ming Xuechang, who all went abroad to confess and urged their families to voluntarily surrender. , saying that China “will never withdraw its troops until it eliminates telecommunications fraud.” The Information Bureau of Myanmar's Wa State responded to media reporters on the 13th and stated that the above three people were indeed members of electronic fraud and were currently under the control of judicial agencies.

;

;;The civil war broke out in northern Myanmar and the situation was tense. The Myanmar authorities promised to completely eliminate e-mail fraud by the end of the year;;;

;

;Recently, some ethnic Chinese minorities in northern Myanmar Ethnic armed forces are fighting the military junta, and the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said that at least 6,000 people have been displaced since the conflict broke out on October 27. The leader of the Chinese ethnic minority armed forces, Peng Deren, is the son of Peng Jiasheng. He claimed that the war was to eliminate telecommunications network fraud.

;

;Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin said that China is highly concerned about the conflict situation in northern Myanmar and urges all parties to immediately cease fire and end the war. "Insist on resolving differences through dialogue and consultation through peaceful means to avoid escalation of the situation, and Take practical and effective measures to ensure the security and stability of the China-Myanmar border."

;

;In the video circulated on the Internet, Wei Qingtao, the second son of the Wei family of the four major families, also said in his confession that war is currently breaking out in Myanmar and may cause disaster at any time. He suffered serious casualties and urged his family to seize the last opportunity to open the park and return the Chinese people in the park to China.

;

;According to CCTV News, since February 2021, domestic tensions in Myanmar have intensified, providing more opportunities for telecom fraud groups to settle in northern and eastern Myanmar and form a "community of interests" with local forces. space. In Myawaddy on the Myanmar-Thailand border alone, there are hundreds of fraud parks. Including fraud groups entrenched in parts of northern Myanmar, there are at least 1,000 parks in total, and more than 100,000 people commit telecom fraud every day.

;

;“The areas where telecom fraud groups gather in northern and eastern Myanmar are only a very small part of Myanmar’s land area, and are mostly areas controlled by ethnic minority local armed forces. However, they have dealt a fatal blow to Myanmar’s national image. "CCTV reported this.

;

;In recent years, the Chinese government has continuously increased cooperation and carried out joint law enforcement operations with Myanmar, Thailand and other countries to severely crack down on telecommunications network fraud in accordance with the law. Especially since this year, China has been even more aggressive. Recently, the police of China, Thailand, Myanmar and Laos launched a special joint operation to combat gambling fraud groups, aiming to severely crack down on telecommunications network fraud and online gambling crimes in the region, and resolutely reverse the high incidence of human trafficking, kidnapping, detention and other crimes. According to incomplete statistics, since September this year, many batches of telecom fraudsters have been escorted back to China from Myanmar, Cambodia and other overseas countries. On October 14, 2,349 telecom fraudsters were transferred from Myanmar to China, setting a record high.

;

;Just as the war broke out, on October 31, Min Aung Hlaing, Chairman of the National Governing Council of Myanmar, met with State Councilor and Minister of Public Security Wang Xiaohong in Nay Pyi Taw. Wang Xiaohong mentioned that the law enforcement and security departments of the two countries will strengthen cooperation in the fields of combating online gambling fraud, counter-terrorism, drug control, law enforcement in the Mekong River Basin, and the security of major projects, so as to safeguard the security and development interests of the two countries.

;

;Some analysts believe that this series of actions demonstrates China’s determination to crack down on telecommunications network fraud. Recently, Zaw Min Tun, spokesperson of the Myanmar National Governing Council, also stated that the Myanmar authorities are determined to completely eliminate online gambling and online fraud in northern Myanmar by the end of 2023.

;TCM hospitals are competing to expand The business field and entry into the "business" of medicinal diet are related to the traditional Chinese medicine theory of "medicine and food come from the same source" that has been passed down for thousands of years and people's increasing awareness of "health blood". Visual China | Picture

;

;"I didn't expect that the one that beats milk tea is the sour plum soup in a traditional Chinese medicine hospital" "Who wouldn't know how to make sour plum soup that only costs one yuan a post"... Social The "Amway posts" posted by netizens on the platform paralyzed the convenient online dispensing system of the Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine overnight - the 1.34 yuan per post of sour plum soup tea bags were sold out.

;

;"Go to a Chinese medicine pharmacy to prepare sour plum soup." This craze set off on social platforms in the autumn of 2023 is not the first time that Chinese herbal tea drinks have made an appearance. As early as 2020, Guangxi Liuzhou Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital attracted attention with the traditional Chinese medicine milk tea launched by the East Hospital Medicinal Food Shop.

;

;After becoming popular on the Internet, Zhejiang Provincial Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital has successively launched Qiuzao Moistening Drink, Three Treasures for Soup, and Winter Tonic Paste Recipes. Among them, the tea soup recipe has a single price Within 20 yuan; Liuzhou Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital has updated the menu of the medicated diet shop and developed six categories of medicated diet, including medicated soup, stir-fry, porridge, herbal tea, pastries, and noodles, with prices ranging from 2 to 55 yuan. wait.

;

;The difference is that the former’s medicated diet products are sold online in the form of medicinal material packages on the Internet hospital platform and are subject to drug management; the latter’s medicated diet products are sold by the Sanfang Catering Company sells offline and operates as a food business.

;

;According to Southern Weekend reporters, in addition to the above two traditional Chinese medicine hospitals, a large number of domestic traditional Chinese medicine hospitals have sold traditional Chinese medicine teas, ointments and other in-hospital agreements on the Internet hospital platform. . These prescriptions are usually labeled with clear efficacy and contraindications, and consumers can place orders by themselves without the need for a face-to-face consultation.

;

;Traditional Chinese medicine hospitals are competing to expand their business areas and enter the "business" of medicinal diet. This is in line with the traditional Chinese medicine theory of "medicine and food come from the same source" that has been passed down for thousands of years and people's increasing awareness of "health preservation". "bloodline". The expansion of the medicated diet business has objectively driven an increase in the number of offline TCM clinic visits.

;

;However, in reality, the business of medicated diet also faces an embarrassing situation due to the "individuation of medicine and food" - whether the product is positioned as a medicine or a food, it affects different business entities. , material selection and regulatory standards also affect consumer expectations.

;

;"Health-preserving medicated diet is different from clinical medicated diet. It must use medicinal materials with the same source of medicine and food approved by the National Health Commission, and the efficacy cannot be discussed. Strictly speaking "It cannot be a clinical medicated diet that has clear therapeutic effects without a doctor's consultation and syndrome differentiation." Song Lucheng, chairman of the Medicinal Diet Branch of the Chinese Society of Chinese Medicine and director of the Department of Traditional Chinese Medicine at the First Affiliated Hospital of Shandong First Medical University, told Southern Weekend reporters.

;

;Suddenly popular a year after its launch, with 80% of female users

;

;Sour Plum Soup was caught off guard by its popularity ".

;

;"On the day before it was removed from the shelves, the single-day sales of sour plum soup even exceeded 40,000 posts." Lu Xiaoai, director of the medical department of Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine, told Southern Weekend reporters. You must know that before leaving the circle, the hospital’s average daily orders for sour plum soup were only a few hundred orders.

;

;In fact, as early as a year ago, on May 31, 2022, Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine began to launch traditional Chinese medicine tea drinks on the Internet hospital platform, including health care products. There are many tea-based prescriptions for dispelling dampness in the spleen, calming the liver and lowering lipids, improving eyesight and moisturizing the eyes. The prescriptions are developed by the studio of famous doctors in the hospital, and the price of a single prescription ranges from 2 to 17 yuan. Sour plum soup will be launched in the summer of 2022. It is composed of four medicinal materials: black plum, hawthorn, licorice and tangerine peel. The prescription details page shows that the prescription has the effects of relieving heat, promoting body fluids and appetizing.

;

;It suddenly became popular a year after its launch. Lu Xiaoai believes that this reflects the current increase in enthusiasm among young people for health care. Sleep disorders, low back pain, cough, irregular menstruation, and fatigue syndrome are the top five diseases treated by Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine in September 2023. They are all common sub-health problems for office workers. Traditional Chinese medicine teas are launched to target common diseases and meet the health needs of young people.

;

;Data provided by Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine shows that the users rushing to buy sour plum soup this time are mainly young women, with over 80% of female users aged 17-30 years old. Users account for 71.25%.

;

;Wang Ci, who lives in Hangzhou, immediately bought the sour plum soup from the Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine, "I thought it could be used as a substitute for milk tea, which is healthy and delicious." Two years ago, 28-year-old Wang Ci was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism due to endocrine disorders. Since then, she has been making tea, making soups, and using medicinal foods to maintain her health.

;

;Hua Bichun, vice president of the Medicinal Diet Research Professional Committee of the World Federation of Chinese Medicine Societies, professor and MD of Fujian University of Chinese Medicine, told Southern Weekend reporters that traditional Chinese medicine Medicinal diet has always been one of the application forms of traditional Chinese medicine. Under the guidance of traditional Chinese medicine theory and through the differentiation of syndromes and diet by TCM doctors, it is often popular in different forms in different regions in different eras, and has penetrated into people's daily life and the methods of disease prevention, treatment, rehabilitation and health preservation. In every aspect. "The basic characteristics of traditional Chinese medicine are holistic view and syndrome differentiation and treatment. Traditional Chinese Medicine Dietetics is guided by the theory of Traditional Chinese Medicine, studying the theories and experiences of traditional Chinese medicinal diets and dietary nutrition, and sorting and improving them to make them compatible with modern nutritional therapy and nutritional hygiene. A practical science in medical care that combines science and technology."

;

;"The basic method of treating diseases in traditional Chinese medicine is to use appropriate combinations of drugs, food properties and flavors to form a certain Use prescriptions to treat diseases. In addition to issuing clinical prescriptions, doctors also need to tell patients what they should and should not eat," Song Lucheng said.

;

; From online to offline

;

;TCM hospitals are engaged in the "business" of medicinal diet and It’s not new. What’s new is the business model. Currently, there are two main business models: Internet hospitals and catering stores.

;

;The promotion of medicated diets on the Internet hospital platform has a lot to do with the development of Internet medical services in public hospitals across the country during the epidemic. At that time, a large number of traditional Chinese medicine hospitals across the country used the Internet hospital platform to launch COVID-19 prevention preparations, opening up the online drug purchase process of online billing and home delivery, and extended it to the medicated diet business.

;

;For example, Hebei Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine launched a series of "Epidemic Therapeutic Recipes", "Medicinal Diet Packs" and "Fermented Paste" in December 2022; Xiamen Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine launched Traditional Chinese medicine anti-epidemic prescriptions will be launched in November 2022, and spleen-strengthening and fat-removing tea will be launched in April 2023; before the launch of sour plum soup, Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine also launched two anti-epidemic prescriptions on the Internet hospital platform.

;

;In addition to online prescriptions, the promotion of medicated diet is closer to the path of market-oriented operation, which is to build a medicated diet catering brand offline.

;

;Liu Jing, director of the Treatment and Prevention Center of Liuzhou Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital, told Southern Weekend reporters that since its opening three years ago, the "Food and Medicine in the Same Garden" medicated diet shop has been combined with Guangxi authentic Based on medicinal materials and local climate characteristics, different forms of medicated dietary products such as dishes, soups, porridge, pastries, drinks, and pastries have been launched. Among them, Chinese herbal milk tea is the most popular among young people.

;

;"Traditional Chinese medicine hospitals cannot directly operate catering business to make profits, so we entrust qualified third-party catering companies to produce medicated dietary products. All product formulas are provided by the Treatment and Prevention Center The medicinal diet team develops and the medicinal materials are also applied for by the hospital to ensure the quality of the medicinal materials." Liu Jing said.

;

;Liu Jing introduced that opposite the "Food and Medicine in the Garden" medicated diet shop is the nutrition clinic of Liuzhou Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine, which provides nutrition screening and assessment, nutrition consultation and Guidance and other services, "If consumers who come to dine are looking for more targeted medicinal diets suitable for their personal constitution, they can come to the outpatient clinic for further consultation."

;

;There are different regulations for purchasing medicated diet online

;

;The positioning of medicated diet is different, and the business paths are also different. different.

;

;The medicated diet products launched by the Internet hospital platform are positioned as medicines. Taking the Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine as an example, the prescription details page for traditional Chinese medicine tea clearly states the name of the drug, indications, usage and dosage, contraindications and precautions. In the selection of medicinal materials, in order to ensure the safety and universal applicability of the prescription, substances of the same origin as medicine and food are mainly used, but relatively mild clinical medicinal materials are also selected. When consumers place an order for tea, the system automatically jumps to the online follow-up prescription, and the convenient dispensing clinic doctor issues relevant diagnostic information before entering the payment page.

;

;How to treat medicated diet based on syndrome differentiation and treatment? Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine has set up a questionnaire containing three questions for each agreement party to determine the consumer's constitution. If the checked option does not match the answer, a prompt message "Purchase is not recommended for the time being, and it is recommended to go to the hospital for treatment" will pop up. However, Southern Weekend reporters found that users can enter the page as many times as they want to answer again.

;

;In this regard, the Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine once reminded consumers in a product promotion article that "the original intention of setting the questions is to identify whether this prescription is suitable, not to follow the trend. Just try various answers and choose the one that suits your needs.”

;

;;

;

;Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine purchases traditional Chinese medicine tea online. You need to answer three questions to identify your physical constitution. Screenshot of the convenient medicine purchase system on the Internet platform of Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine

;

;Southern Weekend reporters found that the current management regulations for online purchase of medicinal foods in different traditional Chinese medicine hospitals are not uniform. For example, the self-service medicine purchasing system of Qingyuan Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine Affiliated to Guangzhou University of Chinese Medicine requires that "only those who return for follow-up visits can purchase medicine online." If the system cannot read the hospital's medical records in the past three months, it will not be able to issue medicinal prescriptions online. .

;

;Food and medicinal diet: medicinal materials are limited and efficacy is not mentioned

;

;Compared with the positioning in traditional Chinese medicine hospitals In the medicated diet industry, which is a medicated diet for medicines and has a broader market, medicated diet is usually sold as food. Traditional Chinese medicine pharmacies represented by Beijing Tongrentang, Zhengzhou Dongjitang, and Shanghai Tonghanchuntang are the main body of the medicated diet industry. A few traditional Chinese medicine hospitals use third-party companies to develop food and medicated diet business.

;

;Whether it is a traditional Chinese medicine pharmacy or a traditional Chinese medicine hospital, those operating food and medicinal diets are faced with restrictions on the selection of medicinal materials and the promotion of their efficacy.

;

;;Since 2002;, the National Health Commission has updated the "Catalogue of Substances that are Traditionally Both Food and Chinese Medicinal Materials" many times. A total of 102 substances with the same origin as medicine and food were identified (;including 9 pilot substances;). According to regulations, medicated dietary products for the general public can only use medicinal materials in the catalog of medicinal and edible products as raw materials.

;

;Yang Rui, president of the China Medicinal Diet Research Association, once pointed out in an exclusive interview with China Well-off Network that medicated diet is an industry that "always walks by the river". It is easy to touch the legal red line of "adding drugs to food" or "illegal practice of medicine". However, the current "list of substances that are both food and Chinese medicinal materials according to tradition" is not sound and complete enough. Many of them are in line with people's traditional eating habits and are also traditional Chinese medicines. Substances derived from raw materials, such as pepper, garlic, black beans, etc., are listed in the Chinese Pharmacopoeia, but they are not included in the Food and Drug Substances List.

;

;In addition, health-preserving medicated dietary supplements are different from medicines and cannot be labeled with efficacy. Xu Ying, deputy section chief of the Advertising Supervision and Management Section of the Beijing Haidian District Market Supervision and Administration Bureau, told Southern Weekend reporters that according to Articles 17 and 46 of the Advertising Law of the People’s Republic of China, as well as the Drugs, Medical Devices, and Health Foods Article 2 of the Interim Measures for the Review and Management of Advertising of Formula Foods for Special Medical Purposes stipulates that drugs cannot be advertised casually, drug advertisements must be released after review by the drug regulatory department, and non-drug foods are prohibited from promoting efficacy.

;

;When Liuzhou Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital Medicinal Food Shop opened, the corresponding effects of medicinal food were marked on the menu. After being reminded by relevant departments, the current menu only retains the main Ingredients and dish names have also deleted words related to efficacy.

;

;Liu Jing believes that there should be a difference between the popular science promotion and advertising of medicated diet, and a balance should be found. Medical institutions cannot mention the efficacy of medicated diets in their popular science propaganda, which may put the promotion of medicated diets in an embarrassing situation.

;

;Song Lucheng noticed that some medicated food caterers will cleverly change their statements in order to avoid supervision. Words like aunt' suggest to consumers".

;

;Zhu Danpeng, vice president of the Guangdong Provincial Food Safety Promotion Association and food industry analyst, told Southern Weekend reporters that although the consumption of traditional Chinese medicine tea represented by sour plum soup The frequency has increased, but there is currently no national standard for the medicated diet catering industry, and it is difficult to form a large-scale market at the current level of development.

;

;;

;

;October 29, 2022, Nanning, medicinal diet display site. Huang Yanmei (Guangxi Branch)/China News Service/Visual China

;

;"One person's delicacy may be another person's poison"

;

;Medicinal diet, which is both food and medicine, also needs to be correctly understood and treated by consumers.

;

;After the traditional Chinese medicine sour plum soup became popular, Gu Hua followed the trend and ordered the spleen-strengthening and dampness-removing drink from the Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine. After taking 10 packs and 20 packets, Gu Hua found that he The symptoms of general fatigue and weak spleen and stomach have not improved. "I originally thought that drinking it would make me healthier, but I didn't expect that it would have no effect."

;

;"Although these medicated dietary products are positioned as medicines, they are actually mainly focused on health-preserving effects. Just like fighting a war, medicated diet and clinical medication are all moving towards the same goal. But one is a rifle and the other is a cannon, and the impact of the attack is different." said Xia Yongliang, director of the Department of Traditional Chinese Medicine and Internal Medicine of Zhejiang Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine and a traditional Chinese medicine physician.

;

;Many traditional Chinese medicine practitioners told Southern Weekend reporters that traditional Chinese medicine diets should be "adapted to the time, place and people" and they should not blindly follow trends.

;

;For example, if you have poor sleep, some people need to clear away heat and calm the nerves, some need to replenish qi and blood, and some need to activate blood circulation and remove blood stasis

;

;, symptoms can be improved only by taking tea with appropriate medicinal materials after knowing your own physical constitution. Sichuan and Zhejiang are both very humid, but eating spicy food in Sichuan can remove dampness, but not in Zhejiang. This is the difference between regional dampness and coldness and dampness and heat.

;

;When sour plum soup became popular, "whether ice can be added to Chinese herbal tea" was widely discussed. Xia Yongliang believes that this needs to be based on the individual's physical constitution and the medicinal properties of the tea. To decide, "If a person with a hot body takes a drink that clears away heat and relieves internal heat, such as herbal tea, you can put ice in it. But if the tea is warm in nature and your body constitution is cold, adding ice will reduce the efficacy of the medicine."

;

;"One person's delicacy may be another person's poison." Song Lucheng said.

;In September this year, Henan Zhengzhou Yuren Education Group’s “allowing employees to take loans to support the company” attracted widespread attention. At that time, many employees of the group reported to "Red Star News" that since 2019, the group has been asking employees to borrow 100,000 to 150,000 yuan each from Zhengzhou Rural Commercial Bank in the name of "decoration loans" for corporate use. The total loan amount More than 20 million yuan. According to a report by the CCTV Financial Channel in September, the statistical table released by the group's finance showed that in January 2021, 181 people in the group had loans of 26.02 million yuan in total.

;

;The Yuren Group once promised its employees to provide mortgage guarantees with school buildings and land, and the borrowed money would be used to "get through the difficulties together." The generous conditions proposed were to pay monthly loan interest to employees at a standard of 1.33%. , higher than the bank's 0.66%, and at the same time provide employees with benefits in terms of children's education and property purchase. Since the end of 2021, the group has often stopped paying interest, causing some loans to be overdue and credit damaged, and some employees' loans will also expire.

;

;On August 2 this year, seven employee representatives reported illegal lending to the Henan Supervision Bureau of the State Administration of Financial Supervision. Recently, the Henan Supervision Bureau of the State Administration of Financial Supervision issued a letter of investigation opinion in response to employee representatives. After investigation, Zhengzhou Rural Commercial Bank violated the "three checks" regulations on loans and did not have adequate credit management in the process of issuing consumer loans to employees of Zhengzhou Yuren Education Group. Some employees violated the contract and changed the purpose of the loan, assisting Yuren Group to misappropriate loan funds and obtain certain economic benefits.

;

;This is not the first time that “loans to work” have made news. In September 2022, Lanzhou Public Transport Group proposed that employees borrow from banks in their own names to cover their salaries from June to September. The bus company provided a joint guarantee and was responsible for monthly interest settlement and principal repayment upon maturity; in March 2023, Gome also An "employee loan" plan was launched, and Minsheng Bank credit loans were introduced to alleviate employees' pressure on salary arrears. Before the company pays wages, employees will be reimbursed for loan interest within 30,000 yuan every month, and employees will be responsible for the excess.

;

;Lanzhou Public Transport’s “loan to work” is to pay employees, Gome Group’s “employee loan” is to relieve the pressure of salary arrears, and Yuren Group’s “loan to work” is generally “for the group’s use” ": Let employees take loans in their personal names, and then the employees will hand over the loaned money to the company, and the company promises to repay the money to the employees at an interest rate higher than that of the bank.

;

;Looking at the whole process of the incident, the first thing to ask is, why do companies not conduct social financing in their own names, but instead ask employees to borrow money? There may be problems such as greater operating risks, lack of effective guarantee collateral, and low corporate credit. And if a company borrows money directly from employees, it is a purely private lending relationship, and the company needs to bear repayment responsibilities, and may also be suspected of illegal fund-raising. Yuren Group encourages employees to apply for "decoration loans" from banks in their own names. This is tantamount to taking advantage of the fact that employees have formal work units and complete credit records to use their personal loan qualifications for their own use. Not only did they successfully obtain loans from banks, The borrowers of the money are employees rather than companies, which can be described as "well-intentioned".

;

;So, why are employees willing to help companies get loans to "get through the difficulties together"? "Some employees violated the contract and changed the purpose of the loan, assisting Yuren Group to misappropriate loan funds and obtain certain economic benefits." This sentence in the investigation opinion of the Financial Supervision Bureau shows that the employees involved in the incident were not completely unaware. "Being loaned" means that at least some employees knew where the loan funds were going, but still conspired with the company to complete the loan.

;

;Whether these employees are coveting the "interest difference", or are trying to keep the company and their own positions, or a combination of both, it seems possible at present that a conflict has formed between the employees and the company. substantial collusion. In its opinion, the Financial Supervision Bureau stated that “the whistleblower’s request to change the subject of the loan to Zhengzhou Yuren Education Group is a civil dispute and should be resolved through negotiation or litigation in accordance with civil laws and regulations.” This is also equivalent to stating that, Since employees sign and seal the loan contract, they should bear responsibility.

;

;Not only that, the employees involved may even be suspected of breaking the law. According to Article 175 of the "Criminal Law of the People's Republic of China", for the purpose of making profits through on-lending, defrauding credit funds from financial institutions and on-lending to others at high interest rates constitutes the crime of on-lending at high interest rates and shall be punished with criminal detention, imprisonment or a fine; and according to the Supreme Court's "On the Trial of Private Article 13 of "Provisions on Several Issues Applicable to Laws in Loan Cases", the "Special Loan Use Agreement" signed between Yuren Group and its employees may also have a high probability of being an invalid contract, and disputes between the two parties still need to be resolved through negotiation or litigation.

;

;Looking at this incident, the company cleverly created a pretext to allow employees to use their personal credit for corporate loans, the bank neglected to review the borrower's qualifications and loan purposes, the employees were greedy for the so-called "interest spread" and their current positions, and the supervision was lax. As a matter of fact, all parties are responsible for the incident. The "loan to work" incident also showed that there were problems in the relationship between Yuren Group employees and the company. Let me ask, if a company is so embarrassed that it needs to take out loans in the name of its employees to save itself, what is the point of employees keeping their jobs?  

;

;Unless there is an employee stock ownership plan or option plan, there is only an ordinary employment relationship between the employee and the company. The "loan to work" program of Yuren Group can be called a clever name. This behavior not only avoids illegal fund-raising, but is not an internal financial product of the company, nor does it count as a company directly borrowing money from employees, nor does it count as an employee stock ownership plan or option. The plan is more like an employee debt plan, and the result is a lose-lose situation for both the company and its employees.

;

;In this incident, the behavior of "employees taking loans to support the company" was more like making themselves hostages of the company, and the greed for "interest difference" can also be called "profit-making stupidity". The employment relationship between employees and the company should be one in which rights and responsibilities are equal. "Talk about money" or "talk about feelings" that go beyond legal rights and responsibilities are untenable.

;

;18. Both sides welcome and appreciate the local cooperation that the two countries have carried out, and encourage provinces, states and cities to carry out practical climate cooperation.

;

;;Forest;

;

;In the past six months, Beijing childcare has finally begun to speed up “make-up classes”.

;

;At the end of March 2023, the Beijing Municipal Government issued a document stating that it plans to have 4.5 childcare centers for infants and young children under the age of 3 per 1,000 people by 2025, of which inclusive childcare spaces will account for no less than 60 %. In October, two sub-district nurseries were unveiled.

;

;In the past, Beijing was a "poor student" in childcare: as of the end of 2022, the number of childcare centers per 1,000 students was only 1.3, far behind the national average (2.03) and not as good as Shenzhen (2.0 ), Shanghai (2.12) and Guangzhou (3.58).

;

;Moreover, 95% of childcare institutions in Beijing are for-profit, and there are only 2 public nurseries.

;

;Why is childcare so scarce in Beijing? How to keep up with the pace of the country?

;

;Finding a venue is not easy

;

;It is not easy to find a venue for children. An insider in Beijing's health care system described to Southern Weekend reporters that of the two streets that were the first to open nurseries, one was "squeezed" and the other was "borrowed."

;

; Known as the first street-run nursery in Beijing, it is located in Xiaojing Automobile Station, a remote parking lot in Liuliqiao, Beijing. The Liuliqiao Sub-district Office is located in the corner of this parking lot, and the nursery is also squeezed out of the Sub-district Office's premises.

;

;This is a house of about 80 square meters, compactly equipped with a toilet, pantry, doll house, reading corner and a mini slide. Outdoor activities are held on the football field on the other side of the parking lot. This artificial turf formerly belonged to a badminton hall.

;

;After one month of operation, only 5 children have been enrolled out of a total of 18 places. The teachers’ explanation is that every new student needs to be assigned a teacher to follow him throughout the whole process. Counting the principal, there are 4 teachers in total. , "Actually, our admission schedule has been until next month."

;

;In fact, its location is not ideal. It is backed by a highway. There is only one community within one kilometer nearby, and there is a main car road in front of the parking lot.

;

;As a parent, a reporter from Southern Weekend participated in an enrollment meeting of a Liuliqiao subdistrict nursery school. Many of the parents who came to visit were not residents of the neighborhood. The advantage here is that it is cheap.

;

;“Nursery outside costs 7,000 to 8,000 yuan a month, but here it only costs 3,600 yuan.” A pair of “Beijing drifter” parents from Hunan told Southern Weekend reporters that the elderly at home could not help take care of their children, so they had to I found a nursery near the company, and including meals, the monthly cost was 4,200 yuan. This is almost the cheapest nursery in Beijing. "Except for a public physical fitness classroom, the classroom where children usually stay is only 30 square meters."

;

;But in the end, they failed to make up their mind to deliver it. "If you come here, you need to deliver it in advance in the morning. Counting the delay fee of 50 yuan/hour, the prices on both sides are almost the same."

;

;A person in charge of a childcare institution told Southern Weekend reporters that childcare centers are more sensitive to distance. “Kindergartens can also radiate to nurseries within three kilometers of the surrounding area. It must be at the doorstep. It’s so cold in Beijing in winter, how many people would be willing to hold such a small baby and go out for more than ten minutes?”

;

;Desheng Children’s Center, located in No. 1 Xinfeng Street, Xicheng District, Beijing, is The second childcare center run by a street in Beijing is located in the core area where land is at a premium - Desheng Street. A two-story building with an independent courtyard, the first floor has been transformed into a nursery, and the second floor is still reserved as an early education center.

;

;The person responsible for operating this nursery is Han Xiaoliang, the founder of Huayu Tiancheng (Beijing) Childcare Service Co., Ltd. They originally opened a nursery in Desheng Street, which was a model park in Xicheng District .

;

;In July 2023, Desheng Street introduced Han Xiaoliang’s agency through bidding to operate the Desheng Children’s Center. Han Xiaoliang told a reporter from Southern Weekend, "As long as I don't lose money, I am willing to participate. It can be regarded as making some contributions to the streets."

;

;Beijing’s guide price for inclusive childcare institutions is no more than 20% of the disposable income of residents in the district in the previous year. “The price is no more than 3,900 yuan.” The price of this nursery It is 3,600 yuan per month. Han Xiaoliang said that Beijing requires a teacher-student ratio of 1:7 for kindergartens over two years old. Under normal circumstances, there are 15 to 18 children with five teachers. "We have just maintained a balance of income and expenditure, and still have a slight loss."

;

;In the last week of September, Desheng Street held a round of enrollment briefings. “On-site applications were made for 18 full-day cares and 12 half-day cares,” Han Xiaoliang said, including those who signed up later. , currently more than 50 support spaces are basically full.

;

;The venue for this nursery does not belong to Desheng Street, but is borrowed from other communities. An insider in Beijing’s health system told Southern Weekend reporters, “This used to be a boiler room in a community that was renovated.”

;

;The for-profit nursery that Han Xiaoliang previously opened in Xicheng District also had to wait three or four years for the venue. "It happened that a training school was not available during the epidemic."

;

;The person in charge of a chain kindergarten brand told Southern Weekend reporters that many districts in Beijing no longer approve new kindergartens. The Xicheng District Education Commission is one of the few that actively welcomes everyone to open kindergartens. Even if I have money, I can't find a suitable place."

;

;The above-mentioned person familiar with the Beijing health care system said that even a venue like Liuliqiao is difficult to find, "because we require that the venue must be rent-free."

;

;Han Xiaoliang has also communicated with some streets before, and everyone is generally faced with the problem of space shortage. "Some streets said that they are not enough for office space. Where can I find a house?"

;

; ;

;

;The first street-run nursery in Beijing. Photo by Southern Weekend reporter Luo Huanhuan

;

;Of the 102 streets, 96 have no plans

;

;According to Beijing’s plan, every street will have an inclusive nursery by 2025. In this regard, Southern Weekend reporters contacted a total of 121 streets in the five urban districts of Beijing, Xicheng, Dongcheng, Haidian, Chaoyang, and Fengtai. In addition to 19 streets that still received no answer after repeated calls, 102 of the streets that answered the call 3 are in planning, 3 are under construction, and 96 streets are still unplanned.

;

;Qinglongqiao Street in Haidian District, Longtan Street and Dongsi Street in Dongcheng District are the three streets where nurseries will be opened after Liuliqiao and Desheng.

;

;Currently, the site in Qinglongqiao Street, Haidian District has been completed and is being filed. Longtan Street is speeding up construction and is expected to be completed in early December. Dongsi Street has found a place and is "waiting for approval from above."

;

;In addition, Chaoyangmen Street in Chaoyang District said, "The street has no place to do it now, and we are waiting for the next plan from above." Panjiayuan Street also said, "The space is tight," and Zuojiazhuang Street is planning middle.

;

;"No matter how tight the venue is, the street can find ways to solve it." The above-mentioned insiders of the Beijing health care system said that they all know that this matter is not easy.

;

;Another worrying issue is how many children will be attracted once the nursery is built.

;

;A staff member from the sub-district office told a reporter from Southern Weekend, "Private childcare institutions only have 7-9 children, and it seems that the market demand is not very strong at the moment."

;

;According to survey data from the Social Affairs Department of the Beijing Municipal Development and Reform Commission, as of 2022, the average utilization rate of support seats in Beijing is 35.4%, with the highest being 64.9% and the lowest being only 13%. Most childcare facilities are vacant.

;

;Han Xiaoliang said that another for-profit nursery he runs has a monthly childcare fee of more than 8,000, and the occupancy rate is only 50%. Even the current inclusive nursery on Desheng Street is just full. There was no “hard-to-find” person as imagined.

;

; "There are so many worries about sending children to kindergarten after the age of three, let alone younger babies." Han Xiaoliang believes that the bigger issue now than building a nursery is how to change parents' perceptions. " We always regard two- and three-year-old children as incompetent and ignorant babies, and fail to realize that children also need a space to develop skills."

;

;Although Beijing has launched a pilot program for inclusive childcare and announced that it will subsidize childcare institutions based on the policy of inclusive kindergartens, the specific details are still awaited. The above-mentioned person familiar with the Beijing Municipal Health Commission said that after the city issues the document, the specific details will still be determined by the district government.

;

;The park has been open for more than a month, and Han Xiaoliang has not received any subsidies yet. "They say they will be subsidized, but how? How much? We can only wait now."

;

;Shanghai has already "handed in the papers"

;

;Shanghai, which is a few steps ahead of Beijing, has already seen a phenomenon where it is hard to find a job. In November 2023, data released by the Shanghai Municipal Education Department showed that the utilization rate of inclusive care seats in Shanghai kindergartens has reached as high as 90%.

;

;In 2022, the total fertility rates of Shanghai and Beijing will be only 0.74 and 0.87 respectively. The total fertility rate refers to the total number of children a woman gives birth to in her lifetime. A woman has an average of 2.1 children to ensure that the total population of the next generation does not decrease.

;

;The construction of inclusive childcare has just started in Beijing and has already been handed in in Shanghai. In 2017, Shanghai began to build inclusive child care centers, and the goal set at that time was to add 50 new centers every year.

;

;In 2019, Shanghai took the lead in the country in releasing the "Shanghai Childcare Service Action Plan (2020-2022)", with the goal of opening at least one inclusive childcare center in every street and town in the central city by 2022. The coverage rate of universal child care centers in the city’s streets and towns shall not be less than 85%.

;

;The implementation of this action plan has been included in the supervision and evaluation of the district government’s performance of educational responsibilities, and key indicators have been included in the annual self-evaluation bulletin, becoming an important criterion for assessing the district government’s performance of its duties.

;

;Today, Shanghai has overfulfilled its task. At least one inclusive childcare center has been opened in every street in the central city, with the city-wide coverage reaching 95%.

;

;Chen Weikai, the founder of "Nursing School", is also the deputy secretary-general of the Shanghai Infant Care Services Committee, a professional committee under the Shanghai Early Population Development Association to assist the government in promoting infant care. Service is one of its functions.

;

;Chen Weikai recalled to the Southern Weekend reporter that Shanghai conducted many pilot projects at the beginning, “from the earliest independent childcare institutions, to integrated early childhood care, and even community childcare such as ‘baby houses’. Do it. With a hundred flowers blooming, from the final practice point of view, it is most cost-effective to run kindergartens to solve the problem of parents sending care."

;

;Across the country, Shanghai is the only one where the Education Commission is in charge of child care. In other places, the health commission is in charge of child care. To this end, the Shanghai Municipal Education Commission has specially established a "Child Care Work Office" to encourage kindergartens to extend downwards to open child care classes, requiring "to open as many kindergartens as possible and as many as possible."

;

;Chen Weikai said that Shanghai’s publicization of preschool education is also the best in the country. “In the process of solving the problem of universal preschool education, childcare is also solved.” Data from the Shanghai Municipal Education Commission shows that nearly 1,000 kindergartens in the city have opened day care classes, accounting for 60% of all kindergartens.

;

;Shanghai requires that newly built, renovated and expanded kindergartens all plan to provide childcare classes. Existing public kindergartens will consolidate resources and strive to add more childcare classes, and private kindergartens will actively offer inclusive childcare classes.

;

;Public kindergartens enjoy the same per-student subsidy as a kindergarten degree—31,000 yuan per student per year. Inclusive private kindergartens offer daycare classes with a subsidy of 1,200 yuan per student per year. The Shanghai Municipal Education Commission also provides a one-time start-up fund of 100,000 yuan for each inclusive childcare center to support the purchase of toys, teaching aids, facilities and equipment.

;

;This makes Shanghai almost the city with the lowest childcare fees in the country. Monthly childcare fees for demonstration kindergartens are 700-800 yuan, first-level kindergartens are 270 yuan, and second-level kindergartens are 220 yuan.

;

;Chen Weikai said that in some core areas, kindergartens with the same academic qualifications have to queue up according to age, giving priority to older children.

;

;Kindergarten is the main channel

;

;Among the four first-tier cities in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, Beijing’s action plan was the latest to be introduced.

;

;Shenzhen and Guangzhou issued action plans in 2020 and 2021 respectively. The "Three-Year Action Plan for the Construction of Beijing's Childcare Service System (2023-2025)" will be released in 2023.

;

;Beijing’s goal is to have 4.5 childcare centers for infants and young children under the age of 3 per 1,000 people by 2025, of which inclusive childcare spaces will account for no less than 60%.

;

;According to the above action plan, Beijing will add no less than 62,000 inclusive child care places in the future, of which 30,000 will be provided by kindergartens and another 32,000 will come from streets, companies and other places. form.

;

;The above-mentioned person familiar with the Beijing Municipal Health Commission told Southern Weekend reporters that this plan is dynamically adjusted. “When we made the plan, it was not clear how much preschool resources could be extended to child care classes. I made some estimates. The whole of Beijing is dynamically adjusted, and there will be no restrictions on which part can handle 32,000 and which part can handle 30,000."

;

;Compared with various forms of childcare such as streets and enterprises, kindergartens have obvious advantages. "Of course, this will save manpower, material and resources than building an institution from scratch. The venue is ready-made, it can be approved quickly, and it is standardized. Moreover, parents have gained more trust in the kindergarten after so many years." The person familiar with the matter said. Classes must be the main channel.”

;

;The integration of child care is seen as a shortcut to inclusive child care, and its resistance mainly comes from the kindergarten itself.

;

;Many industry insiders told Southern Weekend reporters that kindergarten teachers generally lack enthusiasm for opening day care classes. Compared with children over 3 years old, the work of children under 3 years old is more demanding and more difficult. Especially for public kindergarten teachers, the salary will remain unchanged and the workload will increase.

;

;Chen Weikai analyzed that since Shanghai’s Education Commission takes the lead in promoting day care, it has stronger execution capabilities than other cities led by the Health Commission.

;

;For many places, kindergartens need to give priority to solving the problem of "large class sizes" when running daycare classes.

;

;In April 2022, when responding to the proposal to promote qualified kindergartens to open inclusive nursery classes to enroll children aged 2-3, Vice Minister of Education Zheng Fuzhi said that it has not yet been fully popularized across the country. In preschool education, although the problem of children aged 3-6 years old having difficulty enrolling in kindergarten has been alleviated, it has not been fundamentally solved. At present, kindergartens in various places have a relatively high proportion of "large class sizes", and there are still millions of children studying in kindergartens across the country who exceed the class quota. "In this case, areas that have achieved full universal access to preschool education must create conditions to add nursery classes. Areas that have not yet fully popularized preschool education, especially those with a low penetration rate, must provide kindergartens for those aged 3-6 and 0-3 years old. The relationship between admission and day care issues should be properly handled and promoted step by step."

;

;Opportunities for professional institutions?

;

;A Shanghai childcare industry entrepreneur told a Southern Weekend reporter that after attending some industry exhibitions recently, he clearly felt that private capital was withdrawing from the childcare industry. “There are only some toy and teaching aid manufacturers participating. , almost no childcare companies can be seen.”

;

;"How can 7,000 yuan and 700 yuan compete?" This entrepreneur has persuaded many friends who wanted to join the game in recent years. "Now capital no longer cares about this."

;

;Youer Academy is a national daycare chain brand. Founder Su Dezhong told Southern Weekend reporters, “In the future, inclusive schools will account for the majority. Starting from 2020, Youer Academy will be more closely related to the government and local state-owned enterprises. Business cooperation".

;

;In his view, kindergartens do not solve the problem of childcare by running daycare classes. “It actually solves the problem of kindergartens. Now kindergartens are facing a transition from ‘hard to find one child’ to ‘hard to find one child’” 'The problem".

;

;The national “14th Five-Year Plan” requires that by 2025, there will be 4.5 nurseries for infants and young children under the age of 3 per 1,000 people.

;

;Su Dezhong made some calculations. Even if there are only 10 million births in the country every year, there will be 30 million people under the age of 3. By 2025, 4.5 places per 1,000 people will be achieved, which is about 6 million places. The actual enrollment rate is only 20%. Today, the enrollment rate in developed countries has reached 50%-60%.

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 09:25:03 +0800 鸡蛋的坏名声从何而来http://www.infzm.com/contents/260593
;;2023-11-15 08:00:00;
;

;Eggs are one of the most easily available and commonly consumed animal-source foods for humans. At present, the global per capita consumption of eggs is about 150 eggs per year, with more than 210 eggs in Europe and 300 eggs in China. In ancient times, eggs were not only food, but also a medicine for treating diseases. Since the 1960s, eggs have had a bad reputation for being unhealthy. For a time, many people were wondering whether they should eat eggs.

;

;;A warning from a cardiologist;

;

;Eggs’ “bad” reputation comes from cholesterol. As early as the early 20th century, scientists discovered through animal experiments that increasing the cholesterol in feed could increase the serum cholesterol levels of animals and promote the development of atherosclerosis in animals. Given that cardiovascular disease has become the leading cause of death in the United States, on June 16, 1948, U.S. President Harry Truman signed the National Heart Act and allocated $500,000 to launch a 20-year study on the epidemiology of heart disease. study, the Framingham Heart Study. In 1957, the Framingham Heart Research Team published a blockbuster study that concluded that elevated serum cholesterol levels were closely related to the risk of cardiovascular disease. In the 1960s and 1970s, scientists successively observed a certain correlation between dietary cholesterol intake, serum cholesterol concentration, and the incidence of cardiovascular disease. Unfortunately, since one egg (about 50 grams) contains about 200 mg of cholesterol, and eggs had become a daily food in the United States at that time, eggs inevitably became one of the "culprits" in the high incidence of cardiovascular disease in the United States.

;

;In 1968, the American Heart Association clearly stated for the first time that in order to reduce the incidence of cardiovascular disease, it recommended limiting dietary cholesterol intake, and for the first time proposed limiting egg consumption to no more than three eggs per week. This may have been the source of subsequent recommendations from nutritional experts or doctors around the world to limit three eggs per week. This recommendation from a group of American cardiologists on limiting egg consumption seems logical and easy to operate. It has been recognized by many and has gradually become an important basis for the United States and other countries in the world to formulate national dietary nutrition guidelines.

;

;The media's fueling has deepened the public's misunderstanding of eggs. The most typical example is the two cover reports on cholesterol in the American "Time" magazine. In 1984, Time magazine's front-page article was titled "Cholesterol and Today's Bad News," and included a picture of a sad, round face on the cover of the magazine. The eyes were made of two fried eggs, and the sad mouth was Use a piece of bacon with both ends bent downward. Although Time magazine did not originate the bad reputation of eggs, its huge influence undoubtedly further deepened the public's association between eggs and "bad" cholesterol. Fifteen years later, Time magazine once again put an egg on the cover. The omelette still had the round eyes, but the mouth had been replaced by a melon with upturned sides, showing a cheerful smile. The corresponding front page The title of the article is "Cholesterol, now the good news." Although this article marked a more scientific and comprehensive understanding of cholesterol by doctors and nutritionists, it did not quickly eliminate the misconceptions that had been instilled in the public.

;

;With the joint promotion of the medical community and the media, the bad reputation of eggs has lasted for more than 50 years. The biggest impact is undoubtedly the laying hen industry. From 1968 to the early 1990s, U.S. egg production basically stagnated, hovering around 4 million tons. During the same period, the U.S. population increased by more than 20%. Obviously, per capita egg consumption in the U.S. continued to decline during this period.

;

;;

;

;In 1984, Time magazine published a report with the title "Cholesterol and the Bad News Now" and included a picture of a sad, round face on the cover. Fifteen years later, the egg appeared on the cover again, with the mouth replaced by upturned melons on both sides, and the corresponding article was "Cholesterol, Now It's Good News." ;(Information picture/picture);

;

;;There is increasing evidence to the contrary;

;

; Incredibly, there is a lack of direct scientific evidence that eating more cholesterol-rich eggs increases the risk of cardiovascular disease. Recommendations by the American Heart Association and others to limit egg consumption are based primarily on three imperfect pieces of evidence. The first is evidence from animal models that excessive cholesterol intake increases serum cholesterol levels and the development of atherosclerosis in animals. , the second evidence is epidemiological surveys showing that a high-cholesterol diet is associated with a higher incidence of cardiovascular disease, and the third evidence is clinical observations showing that high cholesterol intake leads to an increase in serum cholesterol levels.

;

;These three seemingly interlocking pieces of evidence have fatal flaws. Scientists generally use rats, guinea pigs, rabbits and other animals to conduct animal cholesterol feeding experiments. The amount of cholesterol added is much higher than the daily dietary cholesterol intake, and it often needs to reach the pharmacological level to cause changes in serum cholesterol levels. For example, researchers at the University of Arizona once fed a group of guinea pigs 0 (control), 0.08% (equivalent to 600 mg/day for humans), 0.17% (equivalent to 1275 mg/day for humans) or 0.33% (equivalent to 2475 mg/day for humans). mg/day) dietary cholesterol, and a positive relationship was found between dietary cholesterol intake and serum LDL cholesterol. However, in this study, there was no significant difference in serum cholesterol concentrations between guinea pigs fed 0 dietary cholesterol and feed containing 0.08% cholesterol. Serum cholesterol concentrations increased significantly only when higher doses of cholesterol were fed.

;

;Epidemiological survey results on the correlation between dietary cholesterol and the incidence of cardiovascular disease often "fight", leaving the public confused and at a loss as to what to do. Most of the early epidemiological surveys relied on simple correlation analysis to draw conclusions. For example, they only recorded the consumption of eggs, but did not consider the impact of other dietary components, or even other factors that may cause cardiovascular disease, such as smoking and drinking. factors, so the conclusions of this type of research are unreliable. However, this type of research is often more eye-catching due to the large number of subjects involved and long follow-up time.

;

;Since the 1990s, an increasing number of studies have shown that egg consumption, dietary cholesterol, and the incidence of cardiovascular disease have little association. In 1999, researchers from the Harvard School of Public Health published a major study in the Journal of the American Medical Association. The researchers conducted a follow-up study of more than 117,000 people for 8-14 years. After excluding age, After controlling for smoking and other factors that influence cardiovascular disease, the results showed no significant difference in cardiovascular disease risk between those who ate one egg per week versus one egg per day. In 2015, researchers from the Karolinska Institute in Sweden conducted a 13-year follow-up study on more than 60,000 people and also concluded that daily egg intake was not related to the incidence of cardiovascular disease.

;

;Some studies even suggest that eating eggs appropriately will reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease. In 2018, researchers from Peking University, China Academy of Chinese Medical Sciences, Oxford University and other institutions conducted a cohort study involving 500,000 people and found that compared with basically no eggs, moderate levels of egg consumption (an average of 0.79 eggs/day) ), the risk of death from cardiovascular disease was reduced by 18% and the risk of death from hemorrhagic stroke was reduced by 28%. This is similar to the results of a 2003 study by the Hiroshima Radiation Effects Research Foundation in Japan. After following more than 40,000 people for 16 years, Japanese researchers found that people who ate eggs every day had a 30% lower risk of stroke death than those who did not eat eggs. People who ate 1-4 eggs a week had a corresponding risk of death from stroke. reduce. In a study of more than 130,000 adult subjects aged 40-69 in South Korea, researchers from Seoul National University found that among female subjects, compared with consuming less than one egg per week, Consuming more than 7 eggs per week is associated with a lower risk of metabolic syndrome.

;

;Theoretically, randomized controlled trials are the most effective and reliable method to verify the association between dietary cholesterol and cardiovascular disease risk. Most randomized controlled trials have proven that eating 1-3 eggs per day has little effect on serum cholesterol levels, even for some diabetics. In a one-year randomized controlled trial, researchers from Maastricht University in the Netherlands asked volunteers in the experimental group to drink a buttermilk drink containing 1.5 lutein-rich egg yolks every day, while the control group drank no A placebo containing egg yolk found that after one year there were essentially no differences between the two groups in total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and the ratio of total cholesterol to high-density lipoprotein cholesterol. On the contrary, there are some randomized controlled trials that show that eating eggs actually reduces the risk of metabolic syndrome. However, currently this type of randomized controlled trial has problems such as small samples and short observation time, and still needs further improvement.

;

;In 1995, the American Heart Association Guidelines, the National Cholesterol Education Program Guidelines, the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s Nutrition Facts Table all set dietary cholesterol recommendations at less than 300 mg/ days, and it is recommended to reduce the intake of animal-source foods such as eggs with high cholesterol. However, due to the lack of sufficient scientific evidence to prove that consuming normal levels of eggs or other dietary cholesterol is harmful to the human body, since the beginning of the new millennium, relevant agencies formulating dietary guidelines have successively canceled recommendations on limiting the intake of eggs and dietary cholesterol. In 2002, the American Heart Association removed the specific limit of 3-4 eggs per week while maintaining dietary cholesterol guidelines of less than 300 mg/day. In 2013, the American Heart Association officially announced that "there is insufficient evidence to determine whether lowering dietary cholesterol will lower LDL cholesterol" and canceled the dietary cholesterol recommendation of no more than 300 mg/day. Both the 2015-2020 and 2020-2025 editions of the Dietary Guidelines for Americans have removed the recommendation that dietary cholesterol consumption be less than 300 mg/day. According to the "Scientific Research Report on Dietary Guidelines for Chinese Residents (2021)", currently only a few countries in the world, such as India and Australia, individually recommend eggs, and most countries recommend egg consumption of about 3 eggs per week. The "Dietary Guidelines for Chinese Residents 2022" recommends 1 egg consumption per day, and also states that "eggs are rich in nutrients, and the yolks should not be discarded when eating eggs."

;

;;It turns out that there is a feedback mechanism in the body;

;

;Although most current dietary guidelines have canceled the intake limit recommendations for eggs and dietary cholesterol, the public is still concerned about the There are still doubts about eggs containing cholesterol, and they are worried that long-term eating of eggs will lead to increased cholesterol levels in the body and an increase in the risk of cardiovascular disease. Does high dietary cholesterol intake mean high serum cholesterol levels? Not entirely.

;

;Research shows that only about 25% of the body’s cholesterol comes from dietary intake, and the rest mainly relies on its own biosynthesis. Since cholesterol plays an important role in the human body, almost all cells in the human body can synthesize cholesterol. The liver and intestines are responsible for synthesizing about 80% of the daily cholesterol required by the human body. The brain, adrenal glands and reproductive organs can also synthesize cholesterol efficiently. An adult weighing 70 kg synthesizes approximately 850 mg of cholesterol per day. Clinical feeding studies have shown that if dietary cholesterol changes by 100 mg per day, total plasma cholesterol levels will change by an average of 2.2-2.5 mg/dL, which is equivalent to eating an egg only causing a 2%-3% change in serum cholesterol.

;

;It turns out that scientists have discovered that the human body has a feedback compensatory mechanism for cholesterol. That is, when the human body consumes too much dietary cholesterol, the body's ability to absorb and synthesize cholesterol will be limited, and it will also accelerate. Excretion and removal of excess cholesterol, thereby maintaining the balance of serum cholesterol levels.

;

;In 1991, the "New England Journal of Medicine" reported an extreme case of "addiction" to eating eggs. An 88-year-old male has been eating 20-30 eggs a day for at least 15 years, but the doctor found that his blood lipid levels were basically normal, and his serum total cholesterol was also maintained at normal levels, with an average of 5.18 milliliters. mol/L (normal range 3.12-5.72 mmol/L), and the patient did not suffer from atherosclerosis and other diseases related to excessive cholesterol intake. In order to further study this special case, the researchers conducted a randomized controlled trial. The experimental group added 5 eggs per person per day on the basis of the regular diet, and the group without eggs served as the control group. It was found that during the regular diet, the control group ate The absorption rate of ingested cholesterol reached 53%, while during the high-cholesterol diet, which included five eggs, the absorption rate of ingested cholesterol dropped to 46% in the control group, but the 88-year-old only absorbed 18% of ingested cholesterol. . At the same time, the patient's total bile acid synthesis rate was twice that of the control group, which shows that there is a very effective compensatory mechanism in the patient's body. In the case of a large intake of egg cholesterol, on the one hand, the intake of cholesterol will be reduced. Absorption, on the other hand, reduces the body's ability to synthesize cholesterol, thereby maintaining the balance of total cholesterol.

;

;Of course, not everyone responds to dietary cholesterol in the same way. It generally varies depending on genetics, individual metabolic level, gender, age and other factors. Research shows that about 2/3 of people who consume too much cholesterol will not or only have a slight increase in serum total cholesterol. These people, like the above-mentioned 88-year-old man, have an effective cholesterol compensatory mechanism and can adjust the absorption, excretion and synthesis of cholesterol according to their dietary cholesterol intake. But other people may lack a similar compensatory mechanism, and consuming too much dietary cholesterol will cause a significant increase in serum cholesterol.

;

;There is growing evidence that egg or dietary cholesterol intake is not associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease, while egg intake addresses many nutritional deficiencies and may provide overall benefits across the lifespan. It makes an important contribution to health, so most people can eat eggs with confidence. Even some patients with metabolic syndrome or cardiovascular disease can eat them normally, but they cannot eat too much for a long time.
